title: In Medieval times, how did the king maintain power if all the peasants were poor and all were screwed over? - Quora

response.answer_text: The King was “God’s representative on Earth. Killing the ruler, therefore, was not just an act of political assassination; it was also a horrifying desecration of religious values.” So the peasants, the serfs and the tradesman (who often ended up handicapped from their excessive work hours and low pay) did not consider such an option as possible. Kings existed during the Christiandome Empire, and lived in fear of the pope who could excommunicate them and take away their legitimacy. Before the age of Kings and Christiandome, people live in an age of competing tribal war chiefs. At this time, if they were attacked, they could not retreat to their Lord’s castle for protection. They could not rely on their Lord to administer justice on thieves and murderers either. So, essentially what my thesis is, is that people gave up their freedom in exchange for security and also, for their religious beliefs. Remember, the average life expectancy was low for medieval people; so they were less concerned about the immediate, empirical world and more consumed by aspiration for the afterlife.

Not all of the peasants were poor and most of them were not “screwed over”. The relations with their lords were regulated by mutual agreements.King had immediate power only over the peasants in his private domain and over his lords vassals. Vassals of his vassals and peasants on the lands belonging to any of them were outside his direct influence.
